ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Kinetics
Reaction Rates
Rate Equations
Arrhenius Equations
Reactor Designs and Equations
Bioreactors
New Kinds of Reactors
I learned about chemical reactors and expanded my knowledge of kinetics
In this class, I developed the skills for reactor kinetics and different types of reactors, like batch, CSTR, and more complex ones.

I learned about the ins and outs of reactor design, and how chemical engineers contribute to electronics, biotechnology, and other engineering fields. We also learned about how to use reaction mechanisms to determine rate laws for heterogeneous catalysis and other reactions. We also learned how to process reaction data in order to identify key parameters.
I developed the ability to design different types of reactors common in chemical engineering fields, as well as apply the knowledge learned in the course to problems in research being currently done.
kinetics and reactors
I learned how to solve chemical kinetics and reactors problems relating to heterogeneous catalysts, CSTRs, PFRs, PBRs, batch, semibatch, membrane, electrochemical, and other reactors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
-Organized
-Interesting
-Clear course outline that follows the book
-Kind professor and TAs
-Low workload

Weaknesses
-Exams had questions that asked for things like graphing and stuff that we couldn't realistically do in the time, especially those of us without access to printers.

The course was relatively interesting, especially if you have an interest in kinetics or reactor engineering. You gain a good understanding of the ways different reactors work and their design equations.
I don't think both the pre-recorded and virtual live lectures were needed. I think you could've had one or the other.
I think that this course went in depth without being too much work compared to my other engineering classes.

Strengths - The professor and TAs were great. There were many opportunities to ask questions, and lectures were clear and easy to follow. I also loved that Professor Hu met with us individually throughout the semester to discuss our progress. You could tell he really cared a lot about our learning. 

Weaknesses- Sometimes, it was unclear how much we were supposed to know, and we did end up with some surprising concepts on exams, which was frustrating.
The recording prior to lecture were very helpful in grasping some of the material. Lectures were great for asking questions. It could be improved if more example problems were done during lecture.
Pre-lecture videos on top of full virtual lectures was several hours of course material per week.
not a fan of the flipped classroom system; would be more helpful to do the lectures during class instead of pre-recording them
sometimes the explanations were a little confusing and sometimes I felt the exam content wasnt really covered in class

This was the best course I have taken in the chemical engineering department so far! Homework assignments were very fair and provided a good recap of course material (plus, there were only 6 psets so the workload was very manageable). The pre-recorded lectures and readings were a solid background to in-class content. One weakness was that the pre-recorded lecture plus in-class lecture meant we spent a lot of time in class, which I didn't think was necessary. Also, the final was much more difficult than the midterms and problem sets, which caught us by surprise. I strongly recommend that recitation remain virtual, even once classes are in person, as being able to attend from my room and rewatch the recording was incredibly helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It all pretty much worked: recorded lectures, organized lecture notes, recitation once a week, pre-recorded lectures
I think the class should've just been the live virtual lectures.
I think the pre-recorded lectures were really good and I think that they would be useful when we go back to in person classes.
I actually liked having the prerecorded lecture because I could go at my own pace and process the material. I also enjoyed that we had recitations and in-class discussions.

Recordings prior to lecture and balancing live lecture with discussion sections worked well. Furthermore, the professor and TA were both very willing to meet with students on Zoom, which was great given that COVID-19 has eliminated in-person office hours. Providing more detailed lecture notes and example problems could be helpful, as without in-person learning, it is sometimes harder to understand material and to go over problems.
prerecorded lectures were helpful
I liked the pre-recorded lecture aspect of the class, and the virtual recitation went especially well.
I thought having pre-recorded lectures and then in-class discussions were very helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not unless you're ChemE. It's not an insanely difficult class, and the material is rather straightforward, but unless you're ChemE you won't get a ton out of it. The professor is really nice, but it's definitely a ChemE upper level course.
If you're interested in chemical reactors and kinetics, then yes
I would recommend this course to any student interested in kinetics.
I would recommend this course to another student, but I don't see how it's useful for people outside the major. Professor Hu is great, and I did learn a lot.

Yes, I would recommend this course. It is a requirement for the chemical engineering major and is a great class, where you learn a good amount about varying types of reactors. The professor and the TA are both very helpful and kind!
You likely taking this course if you're a ChemE major, so there isn't much of an option there.

Yes! This course was engaging without being weighed down too much by complicated math. Plus, it covers content at the heart of chemical engineering, which is great! I think many courses in this department feel really theoretical and abstract, but CENG 301 felt like something I could easily imagine myself using after I graduate.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Pre-recorded lectures
Prerecorded lectures and live virtual discussions/lectures
There was a pre-recorded lecture and a live virtual lecture.
We also had recorded pre-lectures.
The class was mostly a live virtual lecture, but we also had prerecorded lectures to watch before our live lectures.
Recordings posted prior to live lecture, live lecture and live discussion sections
Recorded lectures and live virtual lecture
Recorded pre-lectures to watch before class, then live virtual discussion with professor during class time. Recorded recitation sessions with professor and TA (usually to ask homework questions).
preclass recorded lectures
Recorded pre-lecture, live virtual lecture, live virtual recitation
